benchmark_details.name: MIXASSIST
benchmark_details.overview: MIXASSIST is an audio-language dataset capturing the situated, multi-turn dialogue between expert and amateur music producers during collaborative mixing sessions. It provides a unique resource for training and evaluating audio-language models that can comprehend and respond to the complexities of real-world music production dialogues.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: The primary objective of the MIXASSIST dataset is to facilitate the development of AI systems that empower musicians by enhancing their mixing capabilities with accessible, context-aware guidance, fostering a co-creative learning environment.
tasks: Conversational AI assistance in music mixing

data.source: Data was collected from seven co-creative mixing sessions involving 12 music producers, with audio segments sourced from The Mix Evaluation Dataset.
data.format: Audio files and structured conversational transcripts
data.annotation: Annotators reviewed and filtered conversational turns based on their pedagogical value, retaining substantive, actionable guidance.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on evaluations comparing generated AI responses and human expert advice in the context of music mixing.
methodology.interpretation: A lower rank indicates better performance among models in generating relevant mixing advice.
methodology.baseline_results: Qwen was found to significantly outperform other models in evaluations, being preferred in over 50% of cases.
methodology.validation: The dataset was validated through both quantitative evaluations using LLM-as-a-judge and qualitative assessments via user studies.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All participants provided informed consent, and PII was redacted during processing.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: Data derived from publicly available sources, ensuring no copyright infringement.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: All participants gave consent for the recording and use of their dialogue for research purposes.
